title: Gummies
description: The definitive ranking of all gummies

s.name: Nerds Crunch
s.description: Innovative, tasty, delicious, and great gummy texture. 10/10 the ultimate gummy.

s.name: Swedish Fish
s.description: Signature flavor and not too sweet.

a.name: Nerds Rope
a.description: These would be S-tier along with Big Chewy Nerds if the form factor wasn’t so goofy. Fun once, but not a repeat purchase.

a.name: Sour Patch Kids
a.description: The perfect sour flavor paired with just the right size candy. But the quality can be inconsistent.

a.name: Trolli Sour Brite Cralwers
a.description: A safe choice that’s never disappointing. Just the right level of sour.

b.name: Sour Patch Watermelon
b.description: Never my first pick, but it’s never let me down, either.

b.name: Trader Joe’s Scandinavian Swimmers
b.description: Better than most gummies, especially in a pinch.

c.name: Mike & Ike
c.description: Never anyone’s first choice, but they grow on you the more you accidentally find yourself forced to consume them.

c.name: Jelly Belly
c.description: There are a few good flavors and the rest are a waste of time and energy. I couldn’t care less whether I eat these or not.

d.name: Swedish Fish Mini
d.description: For some reason these are always hard. Pass.

d.name: Haribo Goldbears
d.description: I think the gummy bears and the plastic bag are the same material.

f.name: Sour Punch Straws
f.description: Good flavor but why are they always moist!?

f.name: Tajin™ Watermelon Rings
f.description: God is dead and we have killed him.

f.name: Giant gummy bear
f.description: Hilarious in theory. A nightmarish gutbuster in reality.

title: Video games
description: Not a list of all the games I’ve played; just games I’ve spent a lot of time in that left strong impressions, good or bad

s.name: Stranger of Paradise: Final Fantasy Origin
s.description: It’s no secret I’m a Final Fantasy stan. I was not expecting such an amazingly-deep action RPG from Team Ninja that simultaneously pays homage to the entire series while crafting something totally unique and innovative on its own. Er, um, I mean… “I’M HERE TO KILL CHAOS!”

s.name: Death Stranding
s.description: The gameplay certainly has flaws but as an atmospheric experience it is awe-inspiring. Kojima’s finest work to-date.

s.name: Sekiro
s.description: The complete package: challenging-but-fair gameplay, incredible story and characters, and breathtaking visuals and art direction. I keep coming back to this game for the most fun, fluid, and polished combat I’ve ever experienced.

s.name: NieR: Automata
s.description: Addictive hack-and-slash gameplay with RPG elements, a roller coaster story, and amazing art direction (characters by Akihiko Yoshida) make this an unmissable experience.

s.name: The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild
s.description: Without hyperbole, quite possibly the greatest video game made to-date. Even 5 years after its release it continues to captivate and inspire us.

s.name: Final Fantasy XII
s.description: Graphics and art direction that are simply out-of-this-world (esp. for Akihiko Yoshida fans). This game remains the most criminally underrated Final Fantasy. The weapons, boss fights, and characters are unforgettable, and it would be a phenomenal game today let alone when it was released over twenty years ago.

s.name: Kingdom Hearts 2
s.description: This game is pure ecstasy to experience, from music to story to the deep action RPG combat system. Though playing the first is a requirement to fully enjoy this.

s.name: Shadow of the Colossus
s.description: It’s hard to overstate how good this game is—an unforgettable fairytale that is fun as hell to play through.

s.name: Final Fantasy X
s.description: Probably THE most important video game to me growing up, and is always a joy to revisit.

s.name: Mega Man Legends
s.description: Peak Mega Man, and peak PS1 graphics. The character design is incredible.

s.name: Castlevania: Symphony of the Night
s.description: Every track is an absolute banger, the level design is a work of art, and even decades later is an absolute blast to enjoy.

s.name: Chrono Trigger
s.description: Easily the greatest 2D RPG ever made, and in the running for best RPG ever made. Simply timeless (no pun intended).

a.name: Bomb Rush Cyberfunk
a.description: The MUSIC in this game. My god! Gameplay and story is dope too. I wasn’t expecting much more than a cheap nostalgia play but was surprised by the love and creativity poured into this title.

a.name: Persona 5
a.description: Absolutely dripping with style and creativity. The previous Persona installments were fantastic, but this was on a whole new level.

a.name: Super Smash Bros. Ultimate
a.description: A love letter to video game history as well as a milestone achievement in and of itself. It single-handedly invented a genre of fighting games while continuing to push its own boundaries of gameplay.

a.name: Super Mario Odyssey
a.description: All the Mario games are good. This is just the way of things.

a.name: Bloodborne
a.description: A flawless game with rich atmosphere and lore that is a true masterpiece. On a very personal note, the combat wasn’t for me.

a.name: Metal Gear Solid 3
a.description: Metal Gear Solid invented a genre and took it to its absolute peak here. This was also the first game I remember geeking out over the interface design.

a.name: Dark Cloud 2
a.description: This is such a jam-packed action RPG. Sure, the story, characters and battles are good. But the real draw here is all the badass minigames from townbuilding to golfing to photography. And—of course—fishing.

a.name: Kingdom Hearts
a.description: On paper, a game mashing together Square Enix and Disney characters should have been horrible. And yet there’s something magical about its idiosynchrasies that works so well.

a.name: ICO
a.description: An unexpected project from an unlikely group of former filmmakers that changed 3D gaming forever.

a.name: Golden Sun
a.description: At a time when RPGs were falling out of fashion, Golden Sun hit all the right notes that are nigh-impossible for a new IP to hit. It felt both refreshingly-new and nostalgically-familiar the first playthrough. Playing Golden Sun 2 is essential to complete the epic story.

a.name: Mystical Ninja Starring Goemon
a.description: A pure nostalgia pick for me but it remains a quirky underrated title for the N64.

a.name: Earthbound
a.description: I didn’t fully appreciate this game till I was older, but man was this game creative and hilarious.

b.name: 13 Sentinels: Aegis Rim
b.description: Brilliant story and a unique work of art all its own. Sci-fi fans should not miss this.

b.name: Devil May Cry 5
b.description: The game that redefined the hack-and-slash genre showed everyone how it’s done. It’s both a fun romp to play casually and an intricate, deep gameplay system to master for the genre enthusiasts.

b.name: God of War (2018)
b.description: I ignored this game initially, expecting to hate it, but came back to it and kicked myself for sleeping on it. I usually don’t enjoy these kinds of games, but something about this hit all the right notes for me.

b.name: Monster Hunter World
b.description: I got really into insect glaive and it was fun taking a break from playing Spider-Man to play anime dragon-slaying Spider-Man.

b.name: Spider-Man
b.description: For as many Spider-Man games that have been made, and for the brainless collect-a-thon this is, this shouldn’t be this fun. And yet it is.

b.name: Undertale
b.description: Paradoxically both a clever satire of RPGs and a good introduction to the genre. And an absolute JAM of a soundtrack.

b.name: Dark Souls II
b.description: I really liked it, OK?

b.name: Dark Souls
b.description: This game is mean. I love it.

b.name: Metal Gear Solid 2
b.description: “I have no idea what I’m doing but I look good as hell doing it.” — Raiden, prolly

b.name: Mega Man Zero
b.description: This is such a tight, well-made action game it’s a shame it had to squeeze into a tiny GBA screen. But a gem nonetheless.

b.name: Mega Man Battle Network
b.description: An unexpectedly fun, thoughtful, offbeat RPG experience. Has little to do with the Mega Man lore but that freedom is also what allowed some bold game design choices that paid off.

b.name: Zone of the Enders
b.description: Probably the most fun mech game ever made, but it could have been taken even farther.

b.name: Metal Gear Solid
b.description: Classic story and characters we all know and love, but as a game its sequels were all improvements. Which is not a bad thing!

c.name: Metroid Dread
c.description: Definitely one of the Metroid games of all time.

c.name: Final Fantasy VII Remake
c.description: I had a ton of fun playing this for the story and nostalgia, but the gameplay was dry and the environment was such a lazy Unreal Engine effort I was honestly surprised the default character model wasn’t one of the enemies.

c.name: Dark Souls III
c.description: Despite loving I (and II—sue me) and despite the excitement of Miyazaki being back at the helm, for the life of me I could not care enough about another installment of this series to get very far. I hear it’s a good game, though.

c.name: Ni No Kuni
c.description: This is a tough one, because I sank a lot of hours into it, and the game was extremely pleasant and relaxing to play. But in hindsight I remember very little standing out. Except for someone on the NA translation team making a Unabomber joke (Unibopper). Those edgelords.

c.name: Final Fantasy XV
c.description: Shining moments of brilliance and heart but a slog to play overall. Though given its development it’s unbelievable it was ever finished.

c.name: Metal Gear Solid 4
c.description: Kojima should have gone the Advent Children route and made this a straight-to-DVD movie.

d.name: Code Vein
d.description: I expected so little from this game and was still disappointed. It’s playable but not much fun.

d.name: Kingdom Hearts 3
d.description: God why was this made? And did they forget about every Square Enix character?

d.name: Horizon: Zero Dawn
d.description: Interesting story but a boring collect-a-thon of a game.

d.name: Donkey Kong 64
d.description: An ambitious game dozens of hours long showcasing the worst elements of Banjo–Kazooie.

f.name: Final Fantasy XIII
f.description: I have never been so hyped for a game and so horribly let down. This is the only game I swore to myself to never let me play again.

f.name: Resident Evil
f.description: This is the worst RC car I’ve ever driven.

title: Albums
description: My favorite albums. Everything C-tier and below is omitted because who am I, Anthony Fantano?

s.name: Future Static: Liminality
s.description: Obsessed with this prog/metalcore/metalpunk band from Australia. Currently trying to figure out how to headbang upside-down.

s.name: Dance Gavin Dance: Jackpot Juicer
s.description: This album is fast, heavy, technical, and groovy, not to mention silly and fun (“One man’s cringe is another man’s tattoo“). Dance Gavin Dance continues to produce increasily-creative music that is a genre unto itself.

s.name: Archspire: Bleed the Future
s.description: Insanely technical, heavy, fast, melodic, and surprisng. Drone Corpse Aviator is an absolute banger. Apologies to the 17 people whose semantic password was exposed.

s.name: Aesop Rock: Spirit World Field Guide
s.description: The BEATS. The beats on this album are nothing short of a spiritual awakening.

s.name: Lucky Daye: Painted
s.description: Lucky Daye over Frank Ocean any day of the week.

s.name: Tame Impala: The Slow Rush
s.description: Lying underneath a poppy sound and catchy beats is surprisingly deep and layered songwriting.

s.name: Anderson .Paak: Malibu
s.description: Smart, groovy, fresh, and endlessly-cool. Paak’s unmatched style and flow is an absolute treat to listen to, and Malibu is a masterpiece of his talents.

s.name: Veil of Maya: Matriarch
s.description: Is this the greatest metal album ever made? In the years since its release it’s aged like a fine wine, with relistens revealing new depth and substance.

s.name: Wintersun
s.description: This might be the greatest metal album ever made. Conceived by the lead singer/guitarist of Ensiferum, this is his opus.

a.name: Masego: Studying Abroad
a.description: Jazzy as hell while retaining unique personality and soul. I’m looking forward to hearing more from this guy.

a.name: DOMi & JD BECK: NOT TiGHT
a.description: The initial release of two young jazz savants to Anderson .Paak’s label can’t be missed. With guest appearances from Mac Demarco, Snoop Dogg, and more, it’s an exciting debut for some pretty tight artists.

a.name: Erra
a.description: Way heavier than a metal band from Alabama has right to be.

a.name: Andrew Bird & The Mysterious Production of Eggs
a.description: Andrew Bird has several lifetimes of musical genius behind him, but this album was the turning point from a talented musician into prolific artist.

a.name: Children of Bodom: Hate Crew Deathroll
a.description: There is no “best” CoB album. But this album showcases the pinnacle of Alexi Laiho’s writing talent and raw energy.

a.name: MF Doom: Mm..Food
a.description: If I had to pick one album out of MF Doom’s vast archive it would probably be the one with Rapp Snitch Knishes and Hoe Cakes

a.name: Kid A
a.description: This is Radiohead’s best album. I will not elaborate further.

b.name: Spiritbox: Eternal Blue
b.description: Talented clean and unclean vocalist, but the real headline here is the guitarist.

b.name: Khruangbin: Mordechai
b.description: It’s a real toe-tapper, that it is.

b.name: Jadu Heart: Melt Away
b.description: This album took a while to grow on me because it created its own itch that only it could scratch. Now it gets heavy plays on a regular basis.

b.name: Rings of Saturn: Gidim
b.description: An incredibly-talented band, but a lot of unrealized potential.

b.name: RY X: Unfurl
b.description: I pronounce this artist ”relax” because I feel so zen listening to any track.
